RelatedSentence: With change most likely to come on the heels of public demand so strong that it ca n't be ignored , the public is encouraged to flood police departments with calls to end police brutality .

Since the advent of social media , the public 's relationship with law enforcement has evolved into one in which the public can instantly call out abusive policing techniques and incidents in the hope that unlawful and inappropriate behavior can be stopped once and for all .

, to the more recent shootings and calls for reform in Albuquerque , N.M. While not every call for reform is answered or even acknowledged , many demanding widespread reform and an end to police brutality argue that posting concerns on social media and call flooding police departments are important steps in demonstrating to the law enforcement community that the American public will not tolerate abusive tactics .

For example , last month when the New York Police Department announced a Twitter campaign known as # myNYPD , asking New Yorkers to post presumably positive photos and interactions with officers , many police reform advocates used the campaign as an opportunity to showcase poor police tactics .

While not all Americans exercise their right to call a police department in order to report inappropriate behavior by officers , it 's completely legal to do so and is protected under the First Amendment - as is posting one 's grievances on social media channels .
An angry tirade in which an individual mocks , condemns , accuses or judges officers is not protected , and it may result in an individual 's concerns not being taken seriously .

A heated exchange with law enforcement that includes profanity and threats will also likely hurt other people 's attempts to reform law enforcement 's procedures and policies , as local police departments often report irate callers using abusive or profane language for harassment to other local law enforcement agencies and sometimes even the FBI .

Groups such as Cop Block , Honor Your Oath , the National Police Misconduct Reporting Project and Photography Is Not A Crime , have spent years educating the American public on a variety of police - related interactions - from what a driver should do if he or she is pulled over at a checkpoint , to what a citizen 's rights are when video and audio recording interactions with police officers .

I could care less if it 's a cop , politician or even a priest , if a tongue lashing is due .......
We 'd all be better off if the police focused on crimes that have actual victims !
So if getting heated while communicating between non-police and police makes the communication illegal ...
we ought to be able to get cops prosecuted for getting heated when communicating , right ?
When they start screaming at people and using profanity , it should cause them the same problems it causes the rest of us .
